The forest is the unity of all elements. “Earth” does not refer to bedrock. Earth refers to soil. Soil, water, and wind give us the forest. Fire is the catalyst for rebirth. Lose any of the four and the unity of the elements falters. Lose any of the four and life begins to die. Imbalance leads to ruin. Too much soil, too much water, too much wind, too much fire and the balance is lost.

The phoenix rises from ashes. He does not rise from a mud pit or a dust storm or a hurricane.

>I'm just... happy to see you, son.
>Well I'm happy to see you too!

Okay, this got to me. Pandora may seem like a blue copy of Earth where the animals have some extra limbs and the people are taller, but an actual, tangible afterlife is what sells it for me. So much of our human struggles are based on this concept of whether the afterlife exists. People promise you eternal salvation and use that to found religions, wars, etc. People fail to be good because they don't believe heaven or judgement exists in the afterlife. But on Pandora it actually exists, just a place where your memories (basically your conscience) are stored, where you can remember or be remembered.

Forget the sexy blue cats and cool vistas, this shit is why Pandora is paradise.

To be fair the vast majority of war in history has had nothing to do with religion. I think the deadliest western religious conflict was the thirty years war, which accounts for like 6% of total war casualties since 400AD. WW1 and 2 account for 50%. We have actually gotten a lot better at killing eachother for retarded reasons as time has gone on.

I’m also not sure how existence in the spirit tree works. Grace seems to be really alive and is able to talk to kiri, unless it’s not some mental projection eywa is using to communicate with her. And especially in pic related scene, neteyam doesn’t seem fully aware or conscious of the fact he’s dead. Which leads me to think it’s either a snapshot of a memory from a specific point in time (he could still be conscious, but it’s his child self from that moment existing perpetually and he’s unaware of anything else) or maybe he’s in some sort of blissed out dream state of forever being an ignorant child just sort of existing in memoryscapes. Or maybe it’s eywa reconstructing all this for jake and neytiri? What does neteyam do when they aren’t there? I like how vague it is honestly, an afterlife shouldn’t be presented as too concrete or “real” because it loses its mystery and transcendental feeling. I’m going to assume he does live on, but in a dreamlike and incomprehensible way to mortals. He’s part of eywa now and probably doesn’t have the same degree of individuated separate existence he did before, that was its happy but still also sad, they can’t know and love their son in quite the way they did when he was living, even if he goes on.

Hardcore Henry is objectively the most important. Not since 400 Blows in 1959 has cinema been so redefined as to how the film is shown for lack of a better word. 400 Blows was so revolutionary that when it first came out it was described as documentary style. However now its just 100% completely normal filmmaking. And not since before it had film been so revolutionized as with Citizen Kane. I assume. And supposedly one or two movies came out right before 400 Blows from the same scene. Bridge On the River Kwai almost beat it by 2 years but I insist the producers held them back particularly with William Holden's performance. That's how important Hardcore Henry is. Maniac from just a few years before was mind blowing and Hardcore Henry made it look like shadow puppets. As a whole movie. They both do generally the same thing.

>>179339429
400 Blows wasn't nearly as revolutionary as people make it out to be. It was an update on the neorealist style. Jules and Jim was actual innovation if we talk about Truffaut. But overall Godard was the innovator. But also he wasn't the first one to do a lot of the things he did. For example the cinema verite handheld camerwork was done before. Watch the movie Little Fugitive for example from 1953. Truffaut was actually inspired by that one, and Godard most likely saw it too. Of course Godard was the one to popularise it plus his aimless non-story, and most importantly the editing techniques were indeed revolutionary so I'm not saying he didn't do shit or anything. Since the idea of the shitpost was to do a faux intellectual observation on Hardcore Henry I would reccomend you to change up 400 Blows to Breathless. Maybe not Little Fugitive since while important, the film at the time got overlooked.

>>179341670
Picture your next 50 years are guaranteed, seems nice. Only pain would be quietly saving up lots of money to make the next move slowly and steadily up, but then getting hit by a bus wasting all that time on self-improvement and preservation. I get the idea of "I could die at any time, better get fucked up a lot" but I'll bet that lands right into "my body hurts from getting fucked up, might as well not try for the future and get fucked up some more". I get it man, Im the second hemmeroids/fissures guy from too much new years cope sex.

Seems to me the safe bet is calculated risk in every direction you can afford. Dont spend all your money just because you might die next day, dont hoard it for 50 years because you think youll need it in year 51, stuff like that. Drink too much? Take a multi, eat food, drink loads of water inbetween. Too much weed? hydrate to get the most you can out of it for less, space it out more. Paycheck to paycheck? Lower your standards of consumerism, skip the yearly phone, buy offbrand, learn to cook. There's thousands of unique ways to attack a lack of happiness if you break down your frustrations to their core parts and find the solution you can achieve. Short of immortality I guess.

>>179341973
It’s a romance but an unconsummated one. Bill hates his wife, his wife hates him, Scarlett hates being ornamental in her husbands life. They both have no home and are in a foreign environment.

The two key scenes are the karaoke bar and the morning after him sleeping with the lounge singer. Scarlett is seething and he’s seething at himself. She feels cheated on. But it’s also good because they are an escape from their loneliness and pain. It wouldn’t be an enduring relationship.

But it’s heartbreaking for a lot of reasons for me. The feeling of unrequited love. The feeling of aging. The feeling of being lost in life. It just communicates a lot of things to an aging old bastard like me.

It’s not just sad, it’s tender and kind but it makes me feel very lonely.
